item.title: Oil Prices Range Bound Amid Macro Headwinds
item.description: Oil held firm in Europe, with CBA highlighting the recent pattern of OPEC+ output cuts that lift prices and macro headwinds that weigh, adding that these headwinds are unlikely to relent as higher interest rates weigh on global growth.

item.title: Metal Prices Slip as Demand Struggles on Global Economic Weakness
item.description: Base metals prices fell, while gold was flat in early London trade, as demand continues to remain subdued, particularly in China.

item.title: Chinese Shares End Lower Amid Cross-Sector Losses
item.description: Chinese benchmarks ended lower, with consumer and software stocks leading the declines, after PMI data showed that service-sector activity growth cooled in June.

item.title: Dollar Expected to Stay Steady Until Data Later This Week
item.description: ING said the dollar is unlikely to see any substantial moves until key data later this week, including ADP jobs data, ISM services figures, and monthly nonfarm payrolls.

item.title: Eurozone Gross Government Bond Supply Set to Decline in July
item.description: Gross government bond issuance in the eurozone should moderate to below €100 billion in July from close to €119 billion in June, ING has forecast.

item.title: Central Banks Right to Continue Tightening, Says Edmond de Rothschild
item.description: Central banks are right to keep raising interest rates to prevent inflation from reaccelerating, and this shouldn’t pose a major threat to the economy, Edmond de Rothschild Asset Management told Dow Jones Newswires.

item.title: China's Export Curb on Chip-Making Metals Prompt Countries to Explore Supply-Chain Diversification
item.description: Beijing’s decision to curb exports of rare minerals alarms South Korea and Japan.

item.title: Singapore's Central Bank Posts Record Annual Net Loss
item.description: Singapore’s central bank posted a record annual loss due to the currency-translation effects of a stronger Singapore dollar and high interest expenses from mopping up excess liquidity in the banking system.

item.title: How China Came to Dominate the World's Largest Nickel Source for Electric Cars
item.description: Across Indonesia, new industrial plants are going up to process chunks of nickel ore for use in electric-car batteries. Five years ago, there were none.

item.title: How British Storm Shadow Missiles Help Ukraine's Counteroffensive
item.description: As Ukraine’s counteroffensive grinds on, Kyiv has been hitting military infrastructure and supply lines deep inside Russian-held territory with long-range Western weapons. WSJ explains what role Storm Shadow missiles play in Ukraine’s strategy.

item.title: Markets Ignore the Looming Debt Peril
item.description: Rates are still rising. The economy will be held back by the need to shore up highly indebted companies.

item.title: Portable Urinal, but Make It Cool: Redesigns Change the Game for Health Products
item.description: Shoppers flock to compression socks and earplugs styled with a younger customer in mind.

item.title: TV's Golden Era Proved Costly to Streamers
item.description: Streaming losses, layoffs and share-price pressures were already leading to an industry retrenchment. Then the writers’ strike hit.

item.title: Meta's Facebook must get user consent before sending personalized ads in certain circumstances, the EU's top court ruled, a surprise element in a broader court decision in which it sided with German competition regulators.
item.description: Meta’s Facebook must get user consent before sending personalized ads in certain circumstances, the EU’s top court ruled, a surprise element in a broader court decision in which it sided with German competition regulators.

item.title: George Soros's $25 billion nonprofit, Open Society Foundations, will cut its staff by about 40% while reorganizing various senior roles, according to a spokeswoman for the foundation.
item.description: George Soros’s $25 billion nonprofit, Open Society Foundations, will cut its staff by about 40% while reorganizing various senior roles, according to a spokeswoman for the foundation.

item.title: The Biden administration is preparing to restrict Chinese companies' access to U.S. cloud-computing services, according to people familiar with the situation, in a move that could further strain relations between the world's economic superpowers.
item.description: The Biden administration is preparing to restrict Chinese companies’ access to U.S. cloud-computing services, according to people familiar with the situation, in a move that could further strain relations between the world’s economic superpowers.

item.title: Hundreds of Palestinian families fled a refugee camp in the West Bank city of Jenin as Israel's largest military operation in the occupied territory in more than two decades stretched into a second day.
item.description: Hundreds of Palestinian families fled a refugee camp in the West Bank city of Jenin as Israel’s largest military operation in the occupied territory in more than two decades stretched into a second day.

item.title: Chinese chip makers and suppliers, gathered in Shanghai for an industry event, were in a grim but defiant mood following a report that the U.S. plans to widen export controls targeting the industry.
item.description: Chinese chip makers and suppliers, gathered in Shanghai for an industry event, were in a grim but defiant mood following a report that the U.S. plans to widen export controls targeting the industry.

item.title: NATO members, unable to agree on a new leader for the alliance amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, extended Secretary--General Stoltenberg's mandate by one year.
item.description: NATO members, unable to agree on a new leader for the alliance amid Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, extended Secretary–General Stoltenberg’s mandate by one year.

item.title: Consumers expect inflation to stay high over coming months but decline in the years ahead to levels closer to those seen before the pandemic, according to recent surveys likely to be welcomed by the Fed.
item.description: Consumers expect inflation to stay high over coming months but decline in the years ahead to levels closer to those seen before the pandemic, according to recent surveys likely to be welcomed by the Fed.
